title: Škoda 7 cm guns
text:
The Škoda 7 cm guns were a family of <a href="Naval%20artillery">naval guns</a> and <a href="dual-purpose%20gun">dual-purpose gun</a>s of the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a> that were developed and produced for the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Navy">Austro-Hungarian Navy</a> in the years before and during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. These guns were actually 66 mm, but the classification system for artillery rounded up to the next highest centimeter. Following the defeat of the <a href="Central%20Powers">Central Powers</a> in World War I and the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian empire the ships of the Austro-Hungarian Navy were divided among the victorious allies and some guns continued to be used until <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Construction.
The 7 cm guns were developed and built at the Pilsen works between 1892 through 1918. The barrel was made of steel with a horizontal <a href="Rifled%20breech%20loader%23The%20sliding%20block">sliding-wedge</a> breech, they used fixed <a href="Glossary%20of%20British%20ordnance%20terms%23Fixed%20QF">quick fire</a> ammunition and most ranged in length between 26 and 45 calibers. There was a single <a href="Hydraulic%20recoil%20mechanism">hydraulic recoil cylinder</a> beneath the barrel and most were aimed by shoulder pads. The G. L/18 was a landing gun which could be taken ashore to provide support for a landing party. Initially these guns were deployed as anti-torpedo boat guns and had an elevation of -10° to +20°. Škoda engineers later developed anti-aircraft mounts which could elevate from -10° to +90°, but the ballistic performance for the guns remained the same.
Acronyms associated with these guns include:
History.
The Škoda 7 cm were mounted aboard <a href="coastal%20defence%20ship">coastal defence ship</a>s, <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a>s, <a href="minelayer">minelayer</a>s, <a href="Monitor%20%28warship%29">monitors</a>, <a href="pre-dreadnought%20battleship">pre-dreadnought battleship</a>s, <a href="protected%20cruiser">protected cruiser</a>s and <a href="submarine">submarine</a>s of the Austro-Hungarian Navy.

Ammunition.
Ammunition was of <a href="Glossary%20of%20British%20ordnance%20terms%23Fixed%20QF">fixed QF type</a>. A complete round measured 66 x 575R and the projectile weighed between .
